34870688.review:
I purchased Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey with the remastered version. I decided to play the original first to see what the first game had to offer. I was just expecting a fun word game. For the most part, that was spot-on.

During Letter Quest, you follow Grimm's journey to go get food. There are multiple levels that he works through on the way. In each level, he has to fight one or more monsters. The monsters take damage based on the words the player spells out. Those words must be made based on the titles that are available in the tile grid. The titles can be swapped for others if the player gets stuck. Over the course of the game, the player is able to unlock books, potions, weapons, and other items that help them towards the end. All of those items can be upgraded with in-game currency that is earned when beating monsters and levels.

Pros:
- The graphics are cute and smooth.
- The titles are easy to read, but can be traded out for other options later on.
- There are multiple save slots.
- Family friendly.
- Levels get progressively more challenging.
- Each level offers four different challenges, which players earn stars for when they beat them.

Cons:
- Some grinding might be necessary in the middle of the game, especially for new players.
- Only offers story mode, which makes the game lose it's replayability.
- Upgrading items can take a lot of time.
- Some achievements can be irritating.

People looking for a fun word game will likely have a good time with Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey. But with the remastered version out, it may be better to purchase that, or both versions, instead. The player can then choose which option is more suited for them.

30658765.review:
I got the remastered edition of this game, which included the original version as well.  Since the remastered version would be bigger and better, I decided to play this version first lest I'd not want to go backwards and ever play it.  After finishing all of the achievements, I can say that I do recommend playing this game.  The fact that they upgraded it and allow you to have both versions without any extra fees says a lot about the developers, who did a solid job making this game.  

The gameplay is basically an RPG version of a game like Boggle, where you have a field of letters to work with to spell out various words.  Unlike Boggle the letters don't have to be connected to each other at all.  Each letter has either a single dot, two dots, or three dots on it, which represents the difficulty in using that letter in a word, as well as how much damage it will deal to the enemy.  You go back and forth as they attack you and you hack away at them with what words you spell, with a basic rule of thumb being, the longer the word the more damage you deal.  As you play through the game you will buy upgrades for your character, equipable books that grant various benefits, and selectable weapons that grant a bonus to one aspect of your character.  

It's kind of an odd idea on face value, but it gives a bit more purpose and development to what can otherwise be a perpetual routine.  Developing your character and making them stronger gives you more of a reason to keep playing as opposed to an arcade style system where you'd just start all over again each time to earn the high score.  After a bit of a learning curve where you feel like you have to grind for a while, you figure out the right pace for replaying earlier levels at higher difficulties for more gems (currency) without having to keep replaying stages to make any progress.  

I think what I enjoyed most about the game as it is designed was the enemies who took damage with multipliers based on certain conditions, such as using letters from a specific part of the board or using certain letters.  It could be a bit annoying sometimes, especially if you weren't given the letter you needed to get the damage multiplier, but there was never a challenge that was too hard to overcome given a bit of grinding or a second attempt with better letter RNG.  For me it just made it so I had to think my moves out a bit more while still trying to get maximal damage, which is far more interesting then only scouring the board for the longest word possible each and every time.

One troubling area for me was how the game replenishes your letters as you spell out different words.  I wouldn't know whether this is true or not, as it would probably require looking at the programming, but it seemed like I got certain combinations of letters more frequently then not.  I'm no Scrabble pro, but my vocabulary isn't half bad and there were several times that the best words I could spell out were the same.  It took away a degree of replayability when the same combinations of letters and words I could spell kept repeating themselves, despite having 15 letters to work with.

A similar issue applies to the final achievement.  This would only apply to those who bother with achievements, but this game's final achievement was quite a grind to earn.  All you have to do is spell out 3,000 words, but by the time you've finished clearing all of the stages you still have 1,000+ words to work on.  There is certainly some range in that aspect as some people might spell out smaller or larger words or have to grind more if they don't get upgrades that dole out more gems, but I doubt my experience was abnormal.  Before I had finished I had fully upgraded every single upgrade possible and was merely going through the motions to get the last achievement.  I don't know if the number of words would carry over if I started a new game on expert mode or not and I didn't want to find out the hard way.

After doing the last achievement it will be some time before I have an interest in going on to the remastered version of this game, but I'm sure I'll enjoy it when my interest returns.  The original version is certainly playable and I would suggest is the better place to start, since now I have something to look forward to moving on.

Letter Quest is what would happen if Scrabble were an RPG. The player is given a small selection of letters to which they must spell out words in accordance to the level's requirements. Some conditions may prevent the player from using certain letters, some may require them to think laterally such as only using corner pieces. There are 40 levels in total with a small story to follow, a number of bosses, and various upgrades to help you along the way. The art style is cute but lacking in animations and the small selection of songs can become quite grating, but all of these problems appear to be fixed in the remastered edition.

One issue I found was that not all official Scrabble words can be played here, along with not being able to play two-letter words, which means the game could become difficult when options were tight. My suggestion is to brush up on your knowledge of words beginning with Q without U. If your literacy in English is moderate-high then you'll have no issue playing through Letter Quest.

30077229.review:
Pretty simple scrabble-like word game with some basic RPG elements.

It was refreshing to play a word game with a little bit of depth to it.

Gameplay looks like this: you write a word and then you damage the enemy. The longer the word, the more damage you'll deal. Some letters do more damage than others too. A core strategy is to find the longest words with the letters like X, Y, Z, Q, K, H, J in them.

But it would be boring if it was the only approach. Many levels have restrictions. Sometimes you can damage the enemy by writing 4 letter words only, or the words with less than 5 letters. Sometimes you need to finish the word with E to do x7 more damage. There are a lot of these mini restrictions/buffs. It makes the gameplay fun. 

You can buy many upgrades with gems (main currency in this game). You can make your weapon do more damage, regenerate life in battle, take less damage from enemy hits, increase your character's HP, get bonus gems at the end of the level and so on and so on. 

The first several hours is really fun and quite challenging. But from mid-late game, when you are strong enough to kill everything - it starts to get a bit boring. It gets extra grindy at the end if you are going for the achievements (especially the 3000 words).

Native English speakers should not have any problems with this game and non-native ones will learn some new words ^^

29776022.review:
TL;DR:  A fun little word puzzle with more than enough to collect for the completionist.  Easily worth the small price tag.

Decent little spelling game.  Mostly, you're just making words from the tiles, though there is occasionally a hangman mini-game mixed in.  Each level can be played in four modes:  regular, timed, special challenge and elite.  Timed was usually the hardest for me (I had to try a few times on some of the levels).  The special challenge and elite really aren't that hard, if for no other reason than that you aren't under time pressure.  If you want to collect and max out all of the toys, you'll be doing a bit of grinding.  

Don't expect any deep RPG elements.  There are a few upgrades, gear options, and heroes.  The heroes have different stats, though I never noticed a compelling reason to use one over another.  Character optimization just doesn't seem necessary.  You can carry a few each of two different potions (one heals and one clears tile debuffs).  But you won't be having conversations, nor do you get any choices that affect the story.    

The story is told in comics at certain points.  It's fairly lame, doesn't pretend to be anything other than silly, and doesn't get in the way.  I had to go back over the comic while writing this because the story made virtually no impression on me.  Easily forgettable, but similarly forgivable.  

The dictionary is fairly good, though it's definitely got gaps.  It didn't recognize heliophobe, for example.  

The art style is consistent with the previews.  The music is OK.  It could use more variety, but I've seen far more expensive games with far worse.

A very enjoyable word game with lots to do and lots to unlock. There is no real story to speak of but the gameplay is good and that's what matters. The difficulty was just right for me - while I was never blocked in progressing, occasionally I would lose a stage. Still, a broad vocabulary is recommended. After a while you'll learn some of the tricks that can be applied here - for example ZZZ is valid word and quite viable damage-wise, too.

The biggest gripe I have with this game is its dictionary, and my issue is threefold: [list]
[*]First, it is very inconsistent in its inclusion of toponyms. "Wyoming" is a valid word but "Nile" is not. Come on... 
[*]Second, the dictionary does not include common swear words, racial epithets and the like. I was expecting a more clinical, adult approach to language and not omitting them. 
[*]The third, lesser problem are the definitions that the game delivers after submitting a valid word. It's admirable that they tried to implement such a feature, but its execution is very rough. When a word can be both a verb or a noun without context, the verb definition is almost always delivered. And the definitions themselves are often... wonky. Like, really obscure. I'll just leave it at that. But, you know, this doesn't affect gameplay at all. I'm just being grumpy here. [/list]

The achievements are well implemented and not problematic for the most part. I look forward to getting them again in the Remastered version sometime in the future.

[b]Basic Breakdown:[/b] Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey, developed by Bacon Bandit Games and published by Digerati Distribution is an ingenious little number that basically ties Boggle/Scrabble in with RPG elements. 

Little Gimm and Rose set out on a journey to defeat any monster they encounter. Your job is to come along for the ride and use some fancy words to get your way out of difficult situations. Better the vocabulary, better the chance of you winning and sometimes it really isn't as easy as it looks.

Honestly, at first glance it looks like a bit of a childish game due to the animation and bulky look of menus, playable blocks and just the general idea that follows this, but it's honestly perfect for all ages as a casual puzzler to lay back with and get yourself really thinking to try and get passed certain levels. 

I enjoy that the difficulty is set in the middle somewhere - Not punishing, and not dead easy. It's pesky in mini-boss fights as well as certain levels (Also hard levels), while not being impossible to get through. It makes winning feel rewarding and for a game to get that right, it has a lot of brownie points from me from the get-go.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Cute, smoothly animated, nicely cartoony, all round really nice.

[b]Soundtrack:[/b] Don't get me wrong, I really enjoy the soundtrack to the levels, menu etc. However, it does tend to grate a bit after a decent amount of play time as there isn't enough variations to how it sounds. I found myself turning the music down if not nearly completely off after the 3 hour mark hit as that was my limit.

[b]Menu:[/b] Isn't really much of one, but for what there is of it; it's nicely set-up, easy and simple enough for anyone of any age to navigate around.

[b]Final Conclusion:[/b] Wonderful little blend of RPG and a family favorite (e.g Scrabble/Boggle/etc), It blends together really nicely for a game that can be enjoyed by anyone of any age. It keeps you thinking, possibly even teaches you new words you had no idea even existed while feeling both engaging and rewarding.

Brain teasers and adorable-ness, how much of a better combo can you get out of a relaxing puzzler?

17739152.review:
Dawno temu grałem w produkcję Pop cap'u o nazwie Bookworm tales, od razu zauważyłem podobieństwo pomiędzy tą gierką a wspomnianą wyżej. 
	Gra Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey jest grą logiczną opartą na modelu Scrabbl'e. Kirujemy krokami (?) śmierci, która musi wykonać szereg zadań. Śmierć jak to śmierć jest uzbrojona w kosę i tu zaczyna się właściwy model gry: zazwyczaj kontrolowalibyśmy postać i klikali aby zadawać ciosy i combosy. Tutaj tego nie znajdziemy: w grze celem jest z dostępnej rozsypanki liter układać jak najdłuższe słowa i klikanie przycisku attack. Im dłuższe słowo tym więcej obrażeń przeciwnikowi postać zada, dodatkowo w grze jest cała masa wyzwań np. użycie pięć razy pod rząd słowa z dwoma tymi samymi literami obok siebie (np. queen), pojawiają się też litery niezbyt często wykorzystywane w języku angielskim i wtedy naprawdę trzeba się ostro napocić. Dodatkowo trafiają się bonusy w kształcie liter zadających większe obrażenia, lub pomagających odzyskać utraconą energię.
Gra nie jest łatwa: już na czwartym poziomie rozgrywki trzeba ostro kombinować, aby słowa były jak najbardziej rozbudowane i wyszukane- ta gra to prawdziwe wyzwanie dla szarych komórek, sprawdzając przy okazji znajomość słówek w języku angielskim. Osoby nie znające tego języka, niech raczej nawet nie uruchamiają Letter Questa, po prostu sfrustrujecie się totalnie :)
	Podczas przechodzenia każdego poziomu zdobywamy kryształy, służą one jako waluta w grze, za którą kupujemy wzmocnienie niektórych liter, kosy, zwiększamy odporność na ataki wroga, czy kupujemy eliksiry uzdrawiające.
Graficznie gra „tyłka nie urywa”, ale jest wykonana bardzo estetycznie w konwencji filmu animowanego, tak samo muzyka jest wzorowana na 8 bitowcach (ale przygrywają też normalne instrumenty muzyczne), jest całkiem przyjemna, dźwięki z kolei są zredukowane w tej grze do minimum.
Pytanie czy warto? Jak najbardziej! Letter Quest to świetna propozycja dla osób, które chcą doszlifować soje słownictwo w języku angielskim, przy okazji je sprawdzając, ta gra to też gratka dla miłośników Scrabble'a i wszelakich typów krzyżówek ,czy słownych gier i zabaw. Gra też nie jest przesadnie droga i w tej chwili kupując ją na Steamie dostaniecie dwie gry: klasyczną i zremasterowaną, każda daje po trzy karty Steam, więc po części wydatek się zwróci.
Polecam!

17661767.review:
[h1]А на що ти здатен заради піцци?[/h1]
Мабуть, чимало людей пам'ятають про таку інтелектуальну забавку як ерудит. Гравці по черзі викладають слова на ігрову дошку і отримують бали. Хто більше набрав того і капці.
Чим не ідеальний базис для комп'ютерної забавки? 

Ним і скористались розробники Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey.
Гра розповідає нам історію про тяжкі будні Смерті. Сюжет подають у невеличких мальованих коміксах. До рівня супер закручених сюжетних ліній монстрів ігрової індустрії він не дотягує, але просту логіку наших дій таки передає, створивши таким чином переходи між різними зонами, в яких є 30 обов'язкових и до десятка бонусних рівнів. 
Процес проходження рівня являє собою розборки нашого протеже з усілякими супостатами, що стали на шляху до смачної, ароматної піцци. І найголовніше - розбирати кролів, духів літніх бабусь та інші плоди бурної фантазії розробників ми будемо за допомогою нашого словникового запасу. Всього в нашому розпорядженні є 12 випадково набраних літер англійської абетки, з яких ми будемо формувати слова. На пошкодження впливає довжина слова та ціна літер. 
Також у доволі нелегкій справі винищення ворогів нам допоможуть поліпшення персонажа (броня, кількість НР тощо) та зброї (є навіть світлова коса. "May the force be with you"), зілля та книжки, які покращують свої параметри в залежності від їх рівня. 

Також варто зауважити, що кожен рівень (навіть боси) мають сумарно чотири рівня складності. Перший - найпростіший, в другому буде обмеження в часі, третій рівень збільшує атаку монстрів або вводить певні правила. Ну і останній рівень добряче перетрусить навіть експертів: кількість життя і напад у мобів зашкалюють за всі розумні межі. Зірочки, здобуті під час вдалого завершення мозголомки, підносять почуття власної значущості до непристойних значень.

Окрім монстрів нам вставлятимуть палки у колеса і самі літери: час від часу деякі літери змінюють властивості. Такі події можуть бути як і достобіса корисними (різноманітні кристали), так і до чортів болючими і неприємними (отрута, шипи, кам'яні блоки тощо). Не варто забувати і про рандом: не раз і не два траплятимуться моменти, коли монстру і вашому протеже залишається здоров'я на один підзатильник, а ви не можете скласти жодного слівця з наявного набору. Особливо великі кількості люті генерують додаткові рівні з непристойно живучими тварюками.

Музичне супроводження цього місива зроблено на трієчку. Один трек на кожну зону це мало. Також в монстриків відсутня анімація. Нібито і дрібничка, але б з нею було б краще.
Словниковий запас гри також доволі нетривіальний. Забудьте про власні назви та лайливі слова. Тільки літературна мова, тільки хардкор! До плюсів словника можна віднести тлумачення (на англійській), які з'являються після введення певного слова.
Що маємо у підсумку? Гарна коротенька гра, яка буде серйозним викликом для знавців англійської. Чудовий подарунок для гравців-філологів і інших товаришів, які з динамічними жанрами ігор на "Ви" і пошепки.

17644425.review:
Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey - эта игра с составлением английских слов.
Вы играете за Гримма, Смерть с косой, ходите по уровням и убиваете привидений, составляя английские слова. Чем длиннее слова, тем больше удар. Убийство монстров даёт вам драгоценные камни (то есть деньги).

В игре 40 уровней, в каждом из уровней по 4 состязания:
1) Просто убить противников.
2) Успеть убить всех за отведённое время.
3) Специальные правила для каждого уровня (усложняющие игру).
4) Особенно сложный этап, где у противника в два раза больше здоровья, и он в два раза мощнее.

В игре очень неплохо сделана прокачка персонажа. Вы можете сделать следующее:
1) Покупать апгрейды, повышающие ваше здоровье, защиту и атаку, также увеличивающие шанс критического урона оружием, и возможность увернуться.
2) Использовать специальные книги, тоже дающие специальные бонусы, после каждого боя книга прокачивается, и улучшается, можно улучшать её до определённого уровня.
3) Покупать зелья - восстанавливающее здоровье или снимающее все негативные эффекты.
4) Особенные апгрейды, дающие преимущества.
5) Возможность сменить героя, которым играешь, на 1 из 3-х.
6) Сменить тип косы-оружия, всего 10 кос, каждая из которых даёт свой бонус, помогающий в бою. Косу можно за деньги прокачивать 5 раз.
7) Сменить внешний вид букв, которыми вы играете.

В игре существуют особо сложные монстры - боссы. Вам также будут помогать особые кристаллы - буквы, восстанавливающие здоровье, увеличивающие атаку или высасывающие здоровье из монстров, они появляются случайно (можно прокачать шанс, увеличивающий их появление).
В игре есть формальный сюжет.
За достижение особых внутриигровых ачивок вы получаете драгоценные камни (деньги), которые можно потратить на апгрейды. Также есть Стимовские достижения, которые не совпадают с внутриигровыми.

В игре нет анимации монстров, только анимация самого Гримма.
Я прошёл игру за 21 час, дойдя до последнего уровня, пройдя все 160 состязаний, выбил все внутриигровые и стимовские достижения, и прокачал всё что можно в магазине.
У игры есть демо-версия в Стиме, которую вам хватит на два часа. Также, если хотите более продвинутую версию, можете взять Remastered версию, в ней новый саундтрек, режим бесконечного боя, и анимированные противники.

Это инди-игра, она мне в целом понравилась. Если вы любите игры типа "Эрудит", играли в серию Bookworm, то вполне можете взять её, вам понравится.
Я рекомендую эту игру для покупки.

17595136.review:
見たままである。配布されるアルファベットから英単語を作って戦うパズルRPG。
時間制限がなく、間違いによる失点もないのでゆっくり考えて楽しめるカジュアルなレベルデザイン。
辞書を使って調べたりなども可能だろう（楽しくないと思うが）。
原形だけでなく複数形や過去形などの変化形も認識してくれるし、アップグレードによる強化や回復アイテムなどもあるため、むしろネイティブには簡単すぎるのではないかという印象。
小学生レベルの語彙しか備えてない私でも余裕で楽しめる。

ルールを聞いただけで予想がつくだろうが、基本は字数が多い単語やQなどの使いづらい文字を使うほど与えるダメージが大きくなる。色の付いた文字を使えば補助魔法がかかったり、敵の妨害攻撃などもある。
死んでしまっても経験値とゴールドは引き継がれるし、クリア済みのステージも自由に行き来できる。
どえれえ易しいので詰まってしまうなどの不安は心配ない。
ある程度知識が必要な英語版のScribblenauts よりも個人的にはオススメできる。

ちなみにスマホ移植版のオリジナルとリマスター版がセットになっており、ライブラリには2本のゲームが登録される。それぞれに別のトレカも付属されるなどプロスチーマーにとっても有難い配慮。
また、公式サイトのFLASH体験版ではサポートされていないがSteam版はちゃんとキーボードに対応しているので安心してほしい。

Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey is a casual word puzzle game with light RPG elements that give the game a unique twist. Whilst the story is almost non-existant, the gameplay is thoroughly satisfying and somewhat addictive, in a way that a lot of casual games tend to be. 

You proceed through mulitple stages, coming up against differing enemiesand bosses in a turn based combat system, where your attacks are determined by the words you can create from a random set of letter tiles; essentially Scrabble. Spelling longer and rarer words rewards you with higher damage. RPG elements are thrown in, in the form of upgrades to your character and their abilities, such as increased damage, resistances, critical hit chance, and so on. There are also unlockable weapons, and two further characters with slight attribute differences.

The premise of the game is excellent, though I feel it lacks a little depth at times. I would love to see the RPG elements of the game expanded upon if there was to be a sequel; maybe having a party of characters; being able to cast status effects rather than just attacks all of the time; less linear progression, etc. There is certainly a lot of potential here.

Ultimately, if you were expecting an RPG like experience, you will probably be disappointed by this title. If you enjoy word puzzle games however, this game is a pleasant change and has an interesting core mechanic that will keep you playing for hours.

As a fan of Bookworm Adventures, I bought this since it looked like quite the same type of RPG/Word-game mashup.

Overall it is pretty fun.  It has the same basic build-words-to-attack mechanic as Bookworm Adventures, but I still feel that that title was more accessible and enjoyable.

The protagonist Grimm here feels quite weak in the beginning, and a few levels into the game the difficulty spikes, requiring upgrades to be purchased to progress further. This is unfortunate, as I feel the game could have added a number of extra quests without much effort to give a feel of constant progress.  Instead it felt like I was constantly retreading old ground on a grind quest to earn gems. This is where it becomes quite obvious that the title was a mobile port (gems = in-app purchases).

Also, as the difficulty increases, the special debuff/damage tiles begin to clutter the board early on.  That gets a bit frustrating to deal with, especially with the quantity thrown onto the board in one turn.  I do believe their presence helps make the game a bit more dynamic, but this could have been tweaked a bit, along with the aforementioned difficulty spike.

Despite those concerns, I still feel the game is easily worth a few bucks and is a good casual game to pass the time. It seems the developers have been cool about updating the game and listening to customer concerns, so that is a plus.

One thing I'd personally suggest to the developers is to fix the fiddly way that the 'Help' button needs to be pressed to find out what a special tile is, or what the current quest is, or stats and other info.  This is where 'tooltips' would be useful.  Hovering the mouse over an item for a second or two could display relevant information somewhere on the screen.  Also, easier navigation with the keyboard would be welcome.

Other than those concerns, I feel this is a pretty nice effort overall.

P.S. The music may get on your nerves after a few loops, so do yourself a favor and lower/mute it in the Options menu!

16608000.review:
This is a game in the style of Bookworm Adventures or Word Realms—you have a handful of letter tiles, and you have to spell words to attack various enemies. Longer words and rarer letters make for more damage, and you go back and forth until either you or the enemy falls over. Simple enough. I'm a big fan of that genre (what few games exist for it, anyway), but unfortunately, this game doesn't really do the genre justice.

This game is a lot easier than Bookworm Adventures or Word Realms, though. For one, you have a massive hand of tiles (20 at once!), so it's not at all hard to spell words. Second, enemies rarely do anything especially bad to you—they do sometimes mess with your tiles, but none of the things they do to you are particularly problematic. You can purchase all kinds of numerical upgrades (increased health, increased damage, etc.); some of the challenge missions basically aren't possible until you do this, but that's more due to strange enemy design than due to actual challenge. Also, letters don't have specific point values, but instead are just ranked into three tiers. This makes it easy to spell words that score decently high, but it also means that there isn't much reward for using really obscure letters.

Once you beat a level, you'll have to go back over it three more times, with different rules each time. There's a time trial, which is exactly what it sounds like. There's a challenge level, which either beefs up the enemies or puts restrictions on what kinds of letters you can use. And there's a "crystal star" level, which is where the real gameplay happens; in crystal star levels, different enemies have different attributes that actually affect what words you can or should use against them (one might take extra damage from words beginning with a vowel, and one might be only damaged by words that involve letters from the corner of your grid). Crystal star levels are actually fun, since the different monsters feel different and are more than just blocks of tofu for you to spell words at. (Outside of the crystal star levels, the monsters feel very, very similar—they might do slightly different attacks to you, but they don't feel differentiated from each other at all.)

As far as presentation goes, the game feels half-assed. The music is awful, the graphics are boring (the monsters are all basically recolors of the same five or six sprites, and they aren't even animated), and while you're not playing this game for a gripping plot, even the paper-thin story is lackluster. This game lives and dies on the gameplay (which isn't really a bad thing, since the gameplay is the most important part of any game, but still), since it doesn't really do anything to make itself pretty.

Overall, this game's only real strength is the price. If you're looking for a word-combat game that actually feels well-made, you're better off playing Word Realms. If you've already beaten Word Realms and Bookworm Adventures and just want something else in the genre, this game will keep you amused for a couple hours, but it won't reinvent your world in any sense. I don't regret the few dollars I spent on it, but neither am I clamoring for a sequel, at least not without some kind of assurance that said sequel would have a lot of improvements to it.

16265832.review:
Letter quest is essentially a scrabble game with RPG elements. You spell words based on random letters (ie, like Bookworm) and deal damage to monsters based on the complexity of your words. You earn gems over time that will let you deal more damage, take less damage, or other miscellaneous effects. There is a story, but it is frankly not very good (Grimm is looking for a pizza...).

Normally I am quite critical of free mobile games being ported to PC with a big price bump. Thankfully Letter Quest is very well done and is worth the price. The mobile version is free, but supported with lots of IAP - the PC version is balanced so that you can play normally and get enough gems normally to afford to upgrades that you need. Plus you can directly type in words and such, so in many ways I feel that the PC version is going to be superior for input purposes.

The developers, who are still active (~9 months after the launch of the game), actually support the game and make it quite fun. The game is going to be a challenge for those who don't have a big vocabulary, but if you play enough the power-ups will help you out a lot. I actually learned a bunch of new words by trial and error and I like that it shows the definition for most words that you can spell (apparently the game dictionary is ~190,000 words).

The graphics are repeated a lot but are vibrant and cute. If there is any constructive feedback I can give, it is maybe that a easy mode can be added for kids. Once you are through the first dozen or two stages you really need to be spelling 5-6+ letter words or you are going to be spending forever grinding for potions.

In all a great find and I hope the developers make some other cool games in the future.

16191355.review:
There are only so many ways to implement a word-based game, searching, unscrambling, typing, so standing out of the crowd can be a bit of an issue. Happily Letter Quest has found a winning formula. A combination of humor and tried and true RPG-lite mechanics incentivise and distract from the fact that you're essentially doing primary school English homework.
The aesthetic is decidedly cartoon-ish and crafted with a younger audience in mind but it shouldn't be off-putting to older players. The story is silly, lighthearted, and sparse but is punched up by the amusing and word-play filled enemy descriptions. Finally the sound track is fun and energetic but it only plays one track per level so the looping can get in your head a little if you spend more than a couple minutes on a given level. If you enjoy them though you're in luck as the soundtrack is included with the base game.
Speaking of school work and a younger audience, it was nice to see the developers not pass up the educational opportunity inherent to this genre. Every time you type a valid word you can choose to see the definition and it displays the definitions of every word you actually use. At first this seems pretty useless, for the most part you'll only be typing words you already know, but it's actually a clever bit of forethought by the developers. As anyone who regularly plays word games or does crosswords can tell you, it's very easy to "cheat" at a game like this and use program to come up with the best words given your letter set. By displaying the definitions of all the submitted words it almost makes using an assist like that actually more educational than just typing words you already know. What I'm saying is expand your vocabulary by embracing the urge to cheat.
As far as the RPG mechanics go they've definitely been paired down for both general simplicity and with the intended audience in mind. You can upgrade several aspects of your character (damage, armor, health), apply various passive buffs that are upgraded though an XP system, unlock weapons, buy potions, and even unlock more characters. Another interesting mechanic is the weaknesses that the bosses have. Things like multiplied damage from double letter words or words with both an E and a S, force you to really think about your word selection. Several of the enemies also will restrict your letter choices by poisoning tiles, locking them down for a few turns, or even changing several after every attack. It's a fairly unique mechanic that helps keep what could be very repetitive battles fresh.
Overall, Letter Quest is very well made, especially for a two man team, and can be enjoyed by most any player but will especially be of interest to fans of the spelling genre and those looking for a light educational experience. It doesn't take terribly long to complete the main levels, 4+ hours, but the inclusion of some hard levels, special objectives to complete on each level, and a number of unlocks definitely make the non-sale price point fair.

16047374.review:
[h1]Are you tired of swords and magic? Are you on the hunt for another and different RPG?
Then Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey might be for you![/h1]

[b]Developer: Bacon Bandit Games
Publisher: Digerati Distribution
Release Date: 20 November, 2014
[/b]

[h1]Letter Quest: Grimm’s Journey is a different kind of RPG which I happened to enjoy greatly.[/h1]

So what’s the deal?
Well you combine random organized letters which appear on your screen and use those to from words like Minotaur and depending on how many letters you used you deal some damage to the evil creature which dares to stand in your way. Some might take one or two words and others take literally a dozen and you might crush under their bulkiness. One can not always be victorious.

If you beat a stage you’ll notice that you only gained one star. Those stars aren’t your rating on how well you’ve done but just an indication that you’ve beaten this level of the stage. Every stage has four level and the last one is a so called Crystal Star level. I doubt I have to tell you that those are actually very hard.
Every Stage has the same levels. Level one requires you to defeat all monsters, level two is a time trial while level three is a special challenge and well level four is an ultra tough crystal star challenge.
So there’s enough for you to do.

Once you progress through the game you’ll encounter various figures on your way to slay all evil!... with the help of words of course.
Anyway. Those figures will aid you in your battle against the vile creatures of evil!
Well for some gems. Nothing in this world is free. Sadly.
Whether you’re in the need for some more health points or you want a [i]bigger[/i] and therefore stronger scythe, they have exactly what you want.

Besides the obvious health points, armor and weapon upgrades you can also buy certain Books which will give you specific bonuses. One let’s you deal 20% more damage with double letter words like Bubble or Battle. Monster drop 8% more gems with another book. You can also upgrade those books. For every evil creature that you spell to death your current book gains experience points. Sweet ain’t it?

Moreover you can also go ahead and buy a health potion so you can take a beating for some longer.

[h1]Quests? I read RPG. So there better be Quests![/h1]

What would any RPG be without Quests? Well no RPG … I guess.
Letters Quest has a ton of Quests for you. With every Quest you complete you gain a certain amount of gems which you’ll need to upgrade yourself or buy some potions.
Quests require you to do certain things like take 200 damage or use broken tiles twice.

There’s just one thing bugging me … The game’s only playable in english.
So if you’re not fluid with the English Language then I’m afraid you either have to have a Dictionary besides you while playing or you better brush up your English skills.

Well if you’re either a native speaker or rather fluent in English I’d say this game is really worth your time. It’s fun, addictive and can be quite frustrating at times. You’ll feel the pain once you look at the random Letters on your screen and you can’t come up with a specific word in order to kill a ghost which takes only damage from 6-Letter words.

Even if you’re not too fluent in english this game could also be a good exercise to brush up your English. Especially since the loading screen gives you some hints on what to spell with the letter Q for example. Like Qua.

So that’s pretty much it.
Go ahead and use the random Letters on your screen to spell words in order to slay those vile creatures! I’ve said pretty much all that I wanted to say at this point.

[h1]If you happen to be a spelling bee …[/h1]

... then this game is definitely something for you. I greatly enjoyed the game and despite its rather cute looks it can be rather challenging at times.
Despite all that I highly recommend it. Especially for you spelling bees out there.

16023243.review:
This game proudly proclaims to be an RPG, I disagree with that label, but still enjoyed the game a lot.
Letter Quest is a turn based combat game where attacks are made by forming words from a 3x5 random field of letters. Certain letters are worth more damage, corresponding to their point values in Scrabble actually.

Battles give you gems which allow you to upgrade various aspects of your character (more damage, more life from potions or more specific things like 40% extra damage from words containing double letters), and it's quite a nice little system. Earning plenty of gems and upgrading your character will make the game a lot easier, but at no point totally break it to the point of being too easy.

The "story" goes through a grand total of 40 stages as you follow Grimm's titular Journey to get a pizza. It's utterly forgettable, but cute enough I guess. Do not expect to play this for the story though. Each of the 40 stages has a normal mode, the first star, a time trial mode where you have to be fast, the second star, a challenge mode where enemies have special traits (like not taking damage from 4 letter words). Getting all three stars in a stage unlocks the hard version, which has stronger enemies and another set of special rules (like not having 'A's in there).

All in all there's plenty to do, and the core gameplay is fun enough to last you through it.
It's not the most innovative or deep game in the world, but I'd still recommend it.

This would be a great game to get children involved in vocabulary, because the object of the game is to use the scrabble-like pieces to form words. The more complex the words, the more damage you do to your opponent, the more loot drops, the better your score etc. This would be a fun game to get kids involved in learning, without the need for their noses to be stuffed into a book. All in all, I think the concept is neat, the layout is simplistic with no real learning curve, and it was fun. I would recommend it to those who would enjoy this type of game.

15926717.review:
Yes! Yeah, I really wholeheartedly recommend it!
For the lovers of word-puzzle games, narrative driven RPG-lights, or for those who played and loved Bookworm Adventures, Letter Quest delivers lots of brain-teasing fun.
Bookworm Adventures (BA) was so much a clear inspiration, one could confuse it as BA's spiritual sequel. It's all there, the stats-enhancing book items, the one-off potions, the funny short dialogues and descriptions. The devs acknowledge the influence in first few levels, but one could argue they nicked truly a lot of it's ideas.
But I think LQ still stands tall on it's own. There's the nice theme of silly macabre grim reaper going for a pizza, the drawings are nice, fluid and distinct, and there's an addition of short semantic explanation of every word you spell. For foreign speakers (like me) and teachers (like - again - me, hope I could play a German version!) it's a godsend fun way of learning more vocabulary.

I like it, and am giving a thumbs up...

But considering that at the time I'm writing this, you have the rare to unique "100% approval" from Steam users who play the game, I was expecting a bit more.

The word game part is fine, the upgrades and variations are okay, the comics and descriptions of the monsters are funny, it's great to see the definitions of words I didn't know existed... but the adventure and combat seems pretty dull so far.  Imagine this game without having to spell words, with just the adventure / combat, if you can just press the spacebar to strike.  It would be walk to the right, hack, hack, hack, hack, walk to the right, hack, hack, finished.  This part of the game is not very exciting.

Now, speaking of hack, imagine a rich roguelike 2d dungeon-crawler, but with the same "words for combat" mechanism, perhaps framed as "spells" rather than strikes since we are "spelling".  How about the meaning of some words can have some bearing on their effectiveness, or what happens when you spell them?  I think that would be fun.

The start of the game that I've played so far is a bit too easy for me.  There needs to be some difficulty setting or another way to make it more or less challenging to suit the player.  Your game is compulsive / addictive, and I'll probably keep playing, but I haven't fallen in love with it (as I was expecting, given the unanimous approval).

Anyway, I'm sorry if this is coming across too negative.  I do like the game, congrats on making a fun and unusual game.  Maybe you can take some of my feedback on board if you make a sequel at some point.

This is a good word game. At its core, you look at a bunch of letters, and try to think of words, and that is of course fun.

But this game makes things more interesting by introducing several layers of circumstantial bonuses and restrictions that change over time to keep it fresh. Enemies that can only be hurt by four letter words, books that boost your long word damage (among others), your letter tiles can be subject to status effects that make it very important to either use them immediately or maybe avoid using them for several turns.

First I'd like to say that I played a lot of word games, and this one has got to be the best so far.
- If you're into word games I highly recommend this.
- If you're not that into word games but likes cute graphics with a lot of achievements and replay-ability and challenge, I also recommend this.
- If you hate word games and well hate how the game looks in screenshots then its not for you :(.

The game is seriously great,  you start with a few levels then keeps going on and on.
Every level can be played 4 times, to collect 4 different stars, But unlike all other games that I know you don't need to play it again but faster or better to get the 2nd star, no thats what I like about the game, every star is different.

 - First time playing the level = get the first star at the end.
 - Click on 2nd star to replay the level but with a timer, You need to finish it before timer runs out.
- 3rd star is a challenge, For an example > Monsters only take damage from words with 4 letters or more, and way more.
 - 4th star is same as first but except all monsters are elite and very powerful.

And you got the store, which you can buy upgrades, potions, items and a lot more, you can also unlock new tiles for the letters to spice things up and there are 3 characters in the game, you can get an idea of the store in the 5th screenshot in the steamstore page.

Countless words to spell, Crystal letters that gives power-ups And the monsters can also use negative effects on some of the letters such as poison or spikes or cracks and a lot more, also there are small quests to achieve as you play to get more money.

The game music ... IM SO CRAZY about it in all seriousness I love it I want to buy the soundtrack
[b]EDIT[/b] 
OMG The dev replied and apparently the soundtrack is in the game's folder included with the game itself, thats so awesome thanks guys : D

The monsters, level and all designs are totally adorable and the animations are outstanding.
There are a lot of achievements to grind on, And a lot of levels and you can play every level 4 times so yeah that can give you more time to play, I am pretty sure I have around 4+ hours in the game than it shows here but they're all offline mostly and steam does not record that.

THIS might interest many people out there, there is no timer when you're typing the word or thinking it so you can take as much time as you want no need to hurry up and mess up.

A lot of monsters to fight, some with special conditions   EX : only takes damage from words with 2 vowels or more. And moooore that makes the challenge even more crazier than it is.

So summing it all up 

[b] PROS [/b] 
1 - Great game, awesome artwork and music.
2 - A lot of levels that are replay-able, great designs on all of them.
3 - A lot of monsters to fight, countless words to spell and special letters.
4 - Kill monsters and finish levels to get crystals to buy upgrades and weapons and more from the store.
5 - Quests to finish as you carry on and you can upgrade yourself and spellbooks.
6 - Up to 40 levels, And after finishing the game you can start new game with expert mode that adds new stuff.
[b] CONS [/b] 
Absolutely nothing. I am being 100% honest here, in all my reviews even when I fall in love with the game there's always cons but not this one, There's a good reason why this game has 100% positive reviews, the devs ... you guys did an outstanding job and my goal is to be one day as good as you guys are in game developing 

TL;DR
- This game is 100% worth it for anyone who likes word games or slightly interested in them, Its tough and takes a lot of time to finish, Has a lot of content, achievements, leaderboards and cards so you cant go wrong, The 7.99$ price is so unfair for this amazing game

A must buy if you're even slightly into this genre.

15685432.review:
[h1]“¿Alguna vez te imaginaste jugar Scrabble vestido como la parca? 7.9/10“[/h1]

Nuestra historia comienza con Grimm, quien en su búsqueda por una pizza termina combatiendo con demonios, con la ayuda de Rose tendrá que superar hordas de fantasmas, demonios, monstruos e incluso conejos. La historia es simple, pero como ya he mencionado a veces la historia se utiliza de mera excusa para la acción.

En Letter Quest, la jugabilidad se basa en combate por turnos, para infligir daño al enemigo tendrás que formar palabras utilizando las letras de una cuadricula de 5×4, aunque eso no es todo pues para matar a ciertos enemigos tendrás que hacer palabras de un determinado numero de letras si quieres causarles daño.

Como era de esperarse las palabras más largas tienen mayor valor que las cortas, aunque utilizar letras raras como la X o Z en una palabra también aumenta su valor, pues las casillas se dividen por 3 clases: Bronce (Simples), Plata (Normales) y Oro (Raras) entre más letras raras y normales utilices al crear palabras mayor daño causarán estas.

Con un diseño colorido y caricaturesco, Letter Quest no se molesta en utilizar un apartado gráfico espectacular. Pues no es necesario, el diseño de los personajes, enemigos y entornos ya es bastante encantador por si solo.

El apartado sonoro destaca por encima del visual, entregando gran cantidad de pequeñas pistas que hacen la jugabilidad más amena. Algo raramente visto en juegos para móvil y aunque no es una banda sonora especialmente memorable si cumple su cometido con melodías que terminarás recordando por horas.

[h1]Pros:[/h1] [list]
[*]Estilo jugable único y muy entretenido.
[*]Gran variedad de items y mejoras.
[*]El juego permite la utilización de gran cantidad de palabras.
[*]Excelente banda sonora. [/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1] [list]
[*]El juego puede volverse muy difícil en ocasiones.
[*]Aunque esto no representa un problema en la mayoría de mis análisis aquí debo destacarlo, pues el juego solo está disponible en Inglés, lo que causará que mucha gente interesada en el mismo se eche para atrás. [/list]

[h1]Conclusión:[/h1]
Letter Quest: Grimm’s Journey es la clase de juego perfecto para todos los jugadores, es simple, divertido y hasta educativo. Es una verdadera pena que se limite a si mismo al solo estar disponible en un idioma, si eres fan de los juegos con mecánicas innovadoras y tienes por lo menos una idea básica del Inglés no dudes en dar a Letter Quest la oportunidad que se merece.

Este análisis fue realizado con una copia del juego facilitada por el equipo de Bacon Bandit Games.

15592232.review:
Recommended for anyone who ever enjoyed the classic board game Boggle, as this is pretty much a slightly shinier version of it.

You use the letters given to you on a randomized board to spell words.  The longer the word/more valuable the letters used (think Scrabble rules, where using 'Z's, 'X's, etc. nets you more points than 'E's), the more damage done to the monsters.  As you defeat monsters and beat levels, you earn gems, which you can then use to purchase various upgrades.

Each level has four "stars" you can earn: the first is simply for defeating all the monsters on a level, the second is typically a time trial, the third is a unique challenge condition to beat the level, and the fourth is a much harder version of the level.  This adds some replay value, as do the achievements.

The story is almost non-existent, but that's not really the point of playing something like this, so it never bothered me.  Graphics are serviceable, and I did not encounter any bugs.

All in all, fun little word game.  Took me about 8 hours to get all but three achievements, and it never felt tedious replaying levels.

You see games on Steam that cost fifteen bucks that look like they should only cost ten at most, then you play said games, and discover they should have cost five bucks or less at launch. I got this game for $4.79 on sale and it feels like a $10 game of high quality at the very least. There are character upgrades, weapon upgrades, multiple weapons, all the currency is in-game, you can grind if you really want to but probably don't need to, there are special conditions that affect the letters you choose to give them a little bonus (crystals) or a detriment (like whirlwinds, reversal, cloners, etc.), and each of the 40 levels has four variations on how to play it. Other than the word-spelling part, the mechanism of which is traditional, the game incorporates some RPG elements, such as you battle through various scenes to defeat enemies with different abilities to modify the letter board, you are given quests involving spelling during battles, you can buy upgrades to improve your hero's performances and you can level-up your books to receive bonus under specified circumstances. All these elements and factors are integrated into the game smoothly so that the word-spelling puzzles become very attractive and addictive. Although grinding may be needed at some point, this game is not hard overall. 15-20 hours are needed in order to complete all the stages, achievements and buy all upgrades in the store.

14403563.review:
Ever since Bookworm Adventures, I've long been a sucker for the word making adventure game genre. While I've never been able to properly engage in a game of Scrabble, I love the gameplay that this particular genre of game affords. 

When I first heard of Letter Quest they were trying to get onto Steam via Greenlight. After much deliberation I picked up a copy of this game via the Humble Store. I fell in love with it instantly. 

I didn't have much time to play through this game though, so after playing a while put it aside and waited for Valve to greenlight this. It sure took Valve an inexplicably long wait, but here are the fruits of two men's (and a lot of Greenlight voters') hard work!

As the store page states, it's a combination of Scrabble and RPG. It's a very light-hearted tale of a very hungry Grimm reaper looking for pizza and battling monsters along the way - the story is told through rather whimsical-looking comic strip scenes. Yew spell wards een awder too keel anemees...sorry. Proper words, I mean. None of the words in that terrible sentence (barring the proper homophones) would work. :P

Throughout the level you get gems for killing monsters and finishing levels (breaking gem piles). This is where the RPG aspect comes into play - kill more enemies, finish more levels, and you can use the gems to better upgrade Grimm's books, attributes, etc. in order for him to better survive the trickier stages.

Nearly everything about this game is just perfect. Perfect cartoony visuals. Take a bow, [url=https://twitter.com/jakemacher]Jake Macher[/url]! Perfect soundtrack. Can't find out who did it, but the chiptune style soundtrack, which you can find in your game files, is gorgeous and fits the game - one of the rare times where it works SO well. Finally, perfect gameplay mechanics. Okay, nearly perfect. While the difficulty scales reasonably well, some of the monsters are rather tough to kill unless you can come up with words that are longer than 4-5 letters consistently!

Otherwise, CTO [url=https://twitter.com/markjasmith]Mark Smith[/url] has done an incredibly solid job on the coding front. It's rare nowadays for a game to be released on day one with no discernibly game-breaking bugs, and for this game to do so despite being coded by practically one person is a monumental achievement. Integration with Steam features like leaderboards, achievements and even Cloud save are also huge pluses. Not to mention that he (at least I presume it's him) is very active in the Steam forums responding to all sorts of questions, bug reports and suggestions regarding the game, and also pushes out updates as well. Rarely do you ever find developers with this kind of enthusiasm and candour.

This game can stand its own against Bookworm Adventures and the ilk, with its own unique brand of wit and charm. Give yourself a pat on the back, Bacon Bandit Games. You guys deserve it.

[h1]When to buy[/h1]
The game's been bundled a few times recently. The [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/373970]remastered version[/url] has recently been released - you can now buy both the remastered and old version in one package! I'd still recommend a pick up at any price point.

[h1][b]9.5/10[/b][/h1]

I think this game is SUPER FUN. If you're a gamer (casual or overall) and love scrabble or boggle [anyone remember that game?], you will LOVE this game. There are 40 overall levels, but there's 4 variations (with increasing difficulty/conditions) of each level, making it a toal of 160 levels. You play as Grim (or 2 other characters that you have to unlock) and have to spell words to beat a variety of monsters. The more monsters you beat, the more gems you earn. Gems are used to buy different upgrades, books (kind of like spells), and potions. The RPG element adds a little extra oomph to this word game, which makes it shine.

Of course, I love word games, so I played all 160 levels. Each level accomplished earns you a star. There's a little story line (displayed in comics), but the focus is on the word game and fighting of the monsters. 

I truly believe that this game is great for all ages. I even recommend it to kids who want to have fun practicing their spelling skills. Love this game!

14259354.review:
You spell words. You kill monsters. Why? For pizza.

[spoiler]As if a whole horde of monsters guarding pizzas wasn't odd enough, I could have just dialed for a pizza delivery instead of questing for a slice of pizza at the end of the day.[/spoiler] Putting that aside, now for the very long game review.

__________________________

What's there to say when it's basically a word game? As long as you have a good vocabulary you're good to go... but not quite. Throw in the idea of RPGs, and you'll need not only your wits, but strength to overcome this arduous journey. The game itself is like scrabble, but it isn't a crossword puzzle. Consider it boggle, but you don't have to link the letters in a line to form the word. That's freedom, and I like the idea of it. Given a set of 15 letters, you try to form words 3-letters or more. 

You think that forming longer words makes you smart and powerful, but I say "That's rubbish." On your quest for pizza, you will find yourself facing some 'smarter' monsters that can only understand certain words you throw at them. If you had the brains but know not how to use it, you will definitely find yourself dead, no matter how much time you spent investing in forming a long word. Naturally, long words do more damage, but would they always? No. Some 'wittier' monsters can only understand baby talk, so insulting them with witty words proves no help in your quest. But I'm sure you are smarter than these monsters guarding pizzas.

By RPG elements inclusion, it isn't you being a hero and saving the day since you're just out hunting for pizza using your trustworthy guide. You equip yourself with books that actually aid you in your journey which automatically writes new experience for itself as you battle your way to the delicacy. You upgrade your stats to aid you in your long battle. You find a new girlfriend and you decide to let her battle for you in the frontline while you take the pizza for yourself. You prove your wits and unlock cool stuff. What more do you want? Oh yes, the pizza.

So let me put my cynical talk aside, the game itself is decent. Difficulty is well balanced, graphics are simple and clean. More importantly, fonts don't hurt your eyes to look at, especially when it's a word game. You will immediately grasp hold of how the game works when new stuff appears which in my view is ideal. Music is alright, and can get repetitive easily but no one said you can't turn it off to play your own songs, so get on with it. As seen in the screenshots, the game plays a campaign story mode, and every stage is the same. Only difference being the difficulty and challenges presented. That much can bore a person with short attention span.

I generally like this game and would definitely recommend it to anyone who likes word games too. Don't forget, it's all for the pizza.

Addictive. As a Scrabble junkie who has run out of opponents (no one wants to play me anymore for some reason...), this scratches the Scrabble itch. It also has charming graphics and tolerable music. Since everything seems to auto-save constantly, this isn't a big problem. Second, I disagree with some definitions and/or word inclusion. But it's a big language out there, after all. Third, it's a bit grindy. Now, that complaint really only applies if you look at it from a "speed thru and never look back" perspective. If, like me, you want an eternal Scrabble board, it isn't going to matter. Just don't expect to beat the game without some standard RPG resource grinding. 
In summary, it's worth every penny. Unless you hate word games.

14227690.review:
Normally, I'm one for the epic fantasy RPGs and MMORPGs. The genre of "role playing game" has never crossed my mind as having a potentially educational aspect to it, much less one that could be simultaneously educational AND fun. However, Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey does it very well. The art style is adorable and smooth, the simplistic story is funny and compelling, and the "special conditions" ensure that gameplay is never stale. Small things aren't forgotten by the developers either -- there's comedic blurbs that explain each monster "history" to you on the right when in combat, and on the left there's definitions of the words you're spelling out. If you're a parent trying to get your kids to entertain the idea of entwining education and fun, or if you're like me (a college student killing time), this game is a blast. It's also fun to play with friends! Just gather a couple of friends around the fastest typer in the group and let everyone shout out words.

Now go get that pizza!

Not for everyone, but a fun diversion for people who enjoy word games.

Monsters will occasionally pop up that take extra damage from words with multiple vowels, are immune to long words, or will sometimes replace a whole row of letters with D's, and so on.  Field hazards cause certain letters to harm you, do no damage, duplicate themselves, etc.  It shakes the game up just enough to stay interesting.  The Crystal Star challenges get a little grindy to prepare for at times, but are completely doable.

You have several upgrades and equips, but as is common for RPG mechanics like this, only about half of them are particularly useful.  Many of the available stat boosts like defense or dodge chance are too small and/or unreliable to really be worth it, and once you unlock Rose there's little reason to use any other character because she specializes in the stats that are actually good.

This is not a bad game! Of the two recent titles that resemble Bookworm Adventures (the other being Words for Evil), this is the more RPG of the pair. It's turn-based, so you can take your time in assembling words and figure out what to do.

That said, while it's not a bad game, I found myself enjoying it less and less as the game went on and it began adding in more and more conditions to the enemies, or the "challenge" stages that consisted of nothing but "enemies have 2x HP". This is a game that expects you to replay earlier levels for more currency to unlock new items every once in a while, and maybe return to them to unlock new paths on "Hard Stages". If you just play the "required" levels, the game actually ends quite early, and there's a bonus world at the end which is sort of an HP sponge slog.

I will also admit I dislike this game's dictionary - it feels incredibly limited, which is ill-suited for a game wherein you need to create words it recognizes as such to play. I know I'm being negative here, but I'm just pointing out that this is not my jam and maybe look at that other title I mentioned if it doesn't click for you. There's a demo to try out which I highly recommend, because this one is gonna be polarizing by playstyle.

We’re back with an educational review today with LetterQuest: Grimm’s Journey!
In this game, you play as what might be described as the most adorable Grim Reaper in history, going through a variety of levels in which you use set amounts of letters to form words to defeat random ghosts and other monster things.

We’re sure it makes sense somewhere, but who cares, this shit is ADORABLE!

Basically, your goal is to form letters of as high a level of complexity as you can manage with the available letters, in order to score points, damage enemies, and thus progress in the level. Think Bookworm Deluxe with RPG elements, essentially.

It helpfully gives you a description of the word you just typed out too, though some oddities were spotted. Didn’t look ‘em up though, so for all we know, they might be right.

The sound work is decent, the graphics are good (and adorable), and the gameplay does what it has to, and even teaches you stuff. Definitely recommended!

Kouen & Lasharus rate this game 8/10

Letter Quest is a pretty fun word game with light RPG mechanics. Essentially, you're a grim reaper-looking dude who's on a quest to get pizza - a much more relatable story than many other games I can think of. On the way, he has to fight monsters, such as ghosts, snakes and giant rabbits - just like going to the corner pizza place in real life. You defeat monsters by spelling words on a Boggle-like board, doing more damage for longer words or words with less common letters. Then you earn points that you can use to buy upgrades.
The game does get a tad repetitive after a while, but it's a fun thing to play for a little while here and there. My only serious complaint is that the game is a mobile port - not a problem in itself, but there are a few cases here and there where it really shows, with instructions to "tap" a button, for example - just little things not exactly meaningful when you're playing on a PC instead of a tablet or some such.

13279986.review:
Letter Quest: Grimm's Journey is a solid title that has plenty of unlockables, enemies waiting to be defeated by your ability to construct words, a story that might make you hungry, an experience appropriate for your children, and an expert mode once you progress far enough in the game.

The gameplay consists of spelling words and utilizing beneficial tiles while avoiding the bad ones as much as possible. The protagonists in the game has different base stats that determine evasion, hp, critical chance, and more. These affect the battles in significant ways and are able to be upgraded in the in-game shop. There are also hangman sections where you guess the word to get the treasure in the chest and merchant sections that allow you to buy items in between battles. It's been quite the bug-free experience too.

The game recognizes a fair amount of words. You can spell slurs, but the game will not recognize them unless they have a non-vulgar definition. Every now and then, an odd definition might pop up (definitions are provided for your perusal after spelling and submitting a word).

This game favors people that are familiar with English. For non-native speakers, I suggest using some aids due to a possible "grindy" nature the game can take on if you can't spell 4-8 letter words regularly. Keep the "ings" and "eds" in mind for increasing word length like winged and winging or touched and touching.

The art style is clean, clear, crisp, and cute. And maybe another c word. Clover? Anyway, some of the special tile sets that you can use vary in their readability. I like the default one and the transparent style. The Word With Friends style made my eyes water when trying to decipher the font. I suppose I'll never play Words With Friends.

I had a good amount of fun with this title as I do enjoy words. If you like spelling and enjoy Scrabble (this is a single player game with some leaderboards, I believe), then feel free to pick it up. You'll get hours of enjoyment and challenge for a fair price. If you ever see this game on sale, then you can definitely pick it up without doubts. 

P.S.
It's far superior to its mobile version. It's always a wonder to see triple A ports that can't even support proper resolutions.

This is a fun and clever game for people who like word puzzles.  It's an rpg where you spell words to attack monsters or unlock chests, collect treasures, purchase and upgrade items and skills, and so on, as you explore a dungeon. 13117640.review:
After finishing both Bookworm Adventures and Bookworm Adventures 2 I knew I that the full depth of the RPG word game genre had not yet been discovered. I knew that there needed to be greater challenges, more powers, more wordcrafting and more stats. Grimm's Journey a firm addition to that genre and delivers on all of the above. 

PROS: This game takes most of the core elements that made Bookworm Adventures great and expounds on them. 

There is a lot of content: Each individual level has 3 more challenges to add both depth and varied game play. So each"level" is really 4 as you attempt to collect all 4 stars. The first star is always a standard play-through, the second is usually a time challenge, the third is a run-through where each monster has special restrictions or weaknesses, and the fourth is hard mode where the monsters are high-powered. This provides a decent amount of extra playtime and provides more choices on what type of game play you are feeling during any session. 

Stats are awesome: The game stats that are tracked are comprehensive. Max damage with and without bonuses, palindromes spelled, the number of times you have used each letter, how many times have you spelled bacon...that is just a few. The list of tracked data is huge and is lots of fun to look over.

CONS:  I really wish there were still even more powers. The "books" that you can equip can help both form a strategy or just generally make your character more powerful. I feel like more options in this category should have focused more on that strategy element 

It is difficult to craft a strategic run during a given level because they are mostly short (2-5 enemies) and a decent number of enemies have powers that can change tiles or prevent you from using certain tiles. In bookworm adventures 1 you could carefully spell short words using left over letters as you purposefully work toward collecting the necessary letters to spell "Nonproliferation". A mode or "book" that protects your tiles from alteration or lockdown would go a long way toward empowering the overly calculating player.

OVERALL:  This is an awesome game that exands the niche RPG, word-game genre. This game is worth every penny and has been a great addition to my "regularly played" game collection.

13066074.review:
A cute game that is best described as a light RPG using mechanics from popular word games.

Progress through zones and defeat monsters using a Scrabble type system of creating words from letter jumbles, enjoyable if you like the idea of a single player Scrabble and taking your time. Additional challenges are condition based such as time limits or letter limit caps which serves to increase variety and challenge difficulty. 

The role playing aspects are fairly light. Clearing a zone or additional challenges in each zone yield gems which are used to purchase both cosmetic and equipment upgrades, increasing your stats or limited use buffs. Chests that may appear in each zone are solved using a system analogous to the popular word game Hangman.

Overall the art style is cute and well designed, and serves as a strong word based puzzle game. Grinding might be an issue for some as some challenges are gated by equipment and your stats. A great addition is the inclusion of word definitions after playing a word, though at present some definitions need some tidying up, something the developers seem keen to do. I can certainly see the potential for this to be used as a useful educational tool after tightening the definitions, but it is equably just as enjoyable as a casual game for those that enjoy word puzzles and word challenges.

13029766.review:
An extremely solid game in the vein of Bookworm Adventures, that is to say, the woefully under-populated "Scrabble combat" genre. A 15-letter word bank with less RNG smoothing than BA creates a slight bit more difficulty inherently, and the game pulls no punches, expecting large words and smart item-purchasing decisions from the very start.

One downside compared to Bookworm Adventures is that specialized / bonus tiles are given at random, with gear and passives to improve your chances, as opposed to being rewarded for creating high-length or high-value words. The game also seems to favor a grindy approach to building up your resources, as the gem flow in the early-to-mid game is a bit unstable, and the potion costs are exorbitant. A larger variety of chest minigames would not have gone unappreciated, for that matter.

Upsides include a MUCH larger array of modifications, gear, and enhancement items, as well as a more robust dictionary. There are some sly references here and there, and a very good stable of achievements and challenges.

Music tracks are regrettably short, and sound effects have punch but unique ones are few and far between. The end result is audio that can become somewhat grating after a straight hour or so of play.

All in all, it's an extremely solid and welcome addition to the genre, but not without its flaws. I'd recommend it over any other game like it that I have played, however, despite those issues.
13029766.developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to write a detailed review!

A couple of points to note:

- crystal letters are given more frequently when you spell longer words, and words with more rare (silver, gold) letters. Words that are 9 or more letters will often cause at least one crystal tile to be created. It is still a random chance, but the chance is increased a lot for longer/better words. I will likely add a quick message/tutorial in the game explaining this, hopefully that will make it more clear.

- I agree that the potion costs are probably too high right now. I'm looking into adjusting some of the prices and difficulty a bit in a future update, I just want to think very carefully about those changes before I make them.

Thanks again for your feedback, I'm excited to keep improving the game!
